title: Disable all Buttons During an htmx Request
raw_code:
on every htmx:beforeSend in <button:not(.no-disable)/> 
           tell it 
               toggle [@disabled='true'] until htmx:afterOnLoad
html_context:
<body _="on every htmx:beforeSend in <button:not(.no-disable)/> 
           tell it 
               toggle [@disabled='true'] until htmx:afterOnLoad">
      
</body>

title: Filter A Group Of Elements
raw_code:
on keyup
           if the event's key is 'Escape'
             set my value to ''
             trigger keyup
           else
            show <blockquote/> in #quotes when its textContent contains my value
html_context:
<input type="text" placeholder="Search Quotes..."
       _="on keyup
           if the event's key is 'Escape'
             set my value to ''
             trigger keyup
           else
            show <blockquote/> in #quotes when its textContent contains my value">

title: Click 'Reset' to get an indeterminate checkbox
raw_code:
on load set my.indeterminate to true

on click set .indeterminate.indeterminate to true
html_context:
<form>
<input class="indeterminate" type="checkbox" _="on load set my.indeterminate to true">
<input type="reset" _="on click set .indeterminate.indeterminate to true">
</form>

title: Using the transition command
raw_code: on click transition opacity to 0 then remove me
html_context:
<button _="on click transition opacity to 0 then remove me">
  Fade & Remove
</button>

title: Concatenate two strings in _hyperscript
raw_code: on click set my.innerText to #first.innerText + ' ' + #second.innerText
html_context:
Hello

World

title: Disable button until request finishes
raw_code: on click toggle @disabled until htmx:afterOnLoad
html_context:
<button
      class="button is-primary"
      hx-get="/example"
      _="on click toggle @disabled until htmx:afterOnLoad">
      Do It
</button>

title: Hyperscript
description: Yes:
raw_code: on click toggle .open on the #menu
html_context:
• Home
    • ...

title: hyperscript & Its Friend htmx
description:
Well, htmx helpfully fires a lot of [events](https://htmx.org/events) that you can respond to, and responding to events
is hyperscript's bread and butter.  Hyperscript *loves* responding to events.
raw_code: on htmx:afterRequest wait 2s then put '' into #messages

title: hyperscript & Its Friend htmx
description: Relax, we can do that quite easily by putting the hyperscript on the message itself instead:
raw_code: on load wait 2s then remove me
html_context: Hyperscript is awesome...

title: hyperscript & Its Friend htmx
description: In fact, let's make that even nicer and fade it out:
raw_code: on load wait 2s then transition my opacity to 0 then remove me
html_context: Hyperscript is *REALLY* awesome...

title: hyperscript
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code: on click transition opacity to 0 then remove me
html_context: Remove Me

title: hyperscript
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code:
on click
             fetch /clickedMessage/
             put the result into #fetch-target-3

title: hyperscript
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code:
on keyup debounced at 300ms
            put my.value into #debounce-target-3

title: hyperscript
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code: on click toggle .red-border on #toggle-target-3
html_context: Toggle Target

title: hyperscript
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code:
on click send doIt to #event-target-3

on doIt remove me
html_context: Event Target

title: hyperscript
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code: on click show #show-target-3
html_context: Hidden Element

title: Install & Quick Start {#install}
description: After you've done this, you can begin adding hyperscript to elements:
raw_code: on click call alert('You clicked me!')
html_context: Click Me!

title: Language Basics {#basics}
description: Going back to our original example:
raw_code: on click toggle .red on me
html_context:
<button _="on click toggle .red on me">
  Click Me
</button>

title: Separators
description: Features are also terminated by an `end`:
raw_code:
on click
  log "Clicked!"
end

title: Separators
description: The script ends:
raw_code: on click if true log 'Clicked!'
html_context:
<button _="on click if true log 'Clicked!'">
Click Me
</button>

title: Separators
description: Another feature starts:
raw_code:
on click if true log 'Clicked!'
           on mouseenter log 'Mouse entered!'
html_context:
<button _="on click if true log 'Clicked!'
           on mouseenter log 'Mouse entered!'">
Click Me
</button>

title: Variables {#variables}
description: Here is how you create a simple, local variable:
raw_code: set x to 10

title: Variable Names & Scoping {#names_and_scoping}
description:
By using these prefixes it is easy to tell differently scoped variables from one another without a lot of additional
syntax:
raw_code:
set $foo to 10 -- sets a global named $foo
set :bar to 20 -- sets an element scoped variable named :bar

title: Scoping Modifiers {#scoping_modifiers}
description: A variable with a `global` prefix is a global
raw_code: set global myGlobal to true

title: Scoping Modifiers {#scoping_modifiers}
description: A variable with an `element` prefix is element-scoped
raw_code: set element myElementVar to true

title: Scoping Modifiers {#scoping_modifiers}
description: A variable with a `local` prefix is locally scoped
raw_code: set local x to true

title: Attributes
description: You can access attributes on an element with the attribute literal syntax, using an `@` prefix:
raw_code: set @my-attr to 10

title: Properties
description:
Hyperscript offers a few different ways to access properties of objects.  The first two should be familiar
to JavaScript developers:
raw_code:
set x to {name : "Joe", age: 35}    -- create an object with some properties
log x.name                          -- standard "dot" notation
log x['name']                       -- standard array-index notation

title: Properties
description:
The next mechanism is known as a [possessive expression](/expressions/possessive) and uses the standard english `'s`
to express a property access:
raw_code:
set x to {name : "Joe", age: 35}    -- create an object with some properties
log x's name                        -- access the name property using a possessive

title: Properties
description:
There are two special cases for the possessive expression, the symbols `my` and `its`, both of which
can be used without the `'s` for possessive expressions:
raw_code:
get the first <div/> then          -- get the first div in the DOM, setting the `results` variable
set my innerHTML to its innerHTML  -- use possessive expressions to set the current elements innerHTML
                                   -- to the innerHTML of that div

title: Properties
description: Finally, you can also use the [of expression](/expressions/of) to get a property as well:
raw_code:
set x to {name : "Joe", age: 35}    -- create an object with some properties
log the name of x                   -- access the name property using an of expression

title: Flat Mapping
description:
The `of` operator flips the order of the property & the element that the property is on, which can sometimes
clarify your code.
raw_code:
set allDivs to <div/>                      -- get all divs
set allParents to the parent of allDivs    -- get all parents of those divs as an array
set allChildren to the children of allDivs -- get all children of those divs as an array

title: Null Safety
description: On an array, only the `length` property will not perform a flat map in this manner.
raw_code:
set example to null
log example.prop     -- logs null, because `example` is null

title: Creating New Objects
description: You can also use [`query literals`](/expressions/#query-literals), discussed [below](#dom-literals), to create new HTML content:
raw_code: make an <a.navlink/> then put it after me

title: Arrays
description: Hyperscript arrays work very similarly to JavaScript arrays:
raw_code:
set myArr to [1, 2, 3]
log myArr[0]           -- logs "1"

title: Arrays
description: You can use the `first`, `last` and `random` keywords, discussed [below](#positional), with arrays:
raw_code:
set myArr to [1, 2, 3]
log the first of myArr  -- logs "1"
log the last of myArr   -- logs "3"
log random in myArr     -- logs a random element from the array

title: Closures
raw_code:
set strs to ["a", "list", "of", "strings"]
set lens to strs.map( \ s -> s.length )
log lens

title: Control Flow
description: As mentioned in the introduction, `end` is often omitted when it isn't needed in order to make scripts smaller:
raw_code:
on click increment :x
              if :x < 3
                put :x into the next <output/>
              otherwise
                put '3 is the max...' into the next <output/>
html_context:
<button _="on click increment :x
              if :x < 3
                put :x into the next <output/>
              otherwise
                put '3 is the max...' into the next <output/>">
  Click Me
</button>
<output>--</output>

title: Control Flow
description:
All commands also support an `unless` modifier to conditionally execute them.
This allows for a very succinct way of expressing branching logic.
raw_code:
on click set error to functionCouldReturnError()
              log error unless no error
html_context:
<button _="on click set error to functionCouldReturnError()
              log error unless no error">
  Log Result
</button>

title: Comparisons & Logical Operators
description: If the left hand side of the operator is `I`, then `is` can be replaced with `am`:
raw_code:
get chosenElement()
if I am the result then remove me end

title: Comparisons & Logical Operators
description: Comparisons can be combined via the `and`, `or` and `not` expressions in the usual manner:
raw_code:
if I am <:checked/> and the closest <form/> is <:focus/>
  add .highlight to the closest <form/>

title: Comparisons & Logical Operators
description: To work around this, you can move the promise-based value out to a separate statement:
raw_code:
get returnsPromise()
if the result and foo() # foo() will not execute if promise resolves to false

title: Loops {#loops}
description: It supports a large number of variants, including a short hand `for` version:
raw_code:
-- a basic for loop
repeat for x in [1, 2, 3]
  log x
end

-- you may omit the 'repeat' keyword for a for loop
for x in [1, 2, 3]
  log x
end

-- you may repeat without an explicit loop variable and use
-- the implicit `it` symbol
repeat in [1, 2, 3]
  log it
end

-- you may use a while clause to loop while a condition is true
repeat while x < 10
  log x
end

-- you may use an until clause to loop until a condition is true
repeat until x is 10
  log x
end

-- you may use the times clause to repeat a fixed number of times
repeat 3 times
  log 'looping'
end

-- you may use the index clause on any of the above
-- to bind the loop index to a given symbol
-- an index clause is any of "index", or "indexed by"
-- followed by a variable name
for x in [1, 2, 3] index i
  log i, "is", x
end

-- you can loop forever if you like
repeat forever
  if I match :focus
    break
  end
  wait 2s
end

title: Aggregate Operations {#aggregate_operations}
description:
For example, if you want to add the class `.foo` to all elements that have the class `.bar` on it, you can simply
write this:
raw_code: add .foo to .bar

title: Math Operations {#math}
description: Hyperscript supports most of the regular math operators:
raw_code:
set x to 10
set y to 20
set sum to x + y
set diff to x - y
set product to x * y

title: Math Operations {#math}
description: with one exception, the modulo operator uses the keyword `mod`:
raw_code: set x to 10 mod 3

title: Math Operations {#math}
description:
Hyperscript does not have a notion of mathematical operator precedence.  Instead, math operators must be fully
parenthesized when used in combination with other math operators:
raw_code:
set x to 10
set y to 20
set sumOfSquares to (x * x) + (y * y)

title: Math Operations {#math}
description:
Hyperscript also offers an [`increment`](/commands/increment) and [`decrement`](/commands/decrement) command for modifying
numbers:
raw_code:
set x to 1
increment x
puts x -- prints 2 to the console

title: Math Operations {#math}
raw_code:
on click
   increment @data-counter
   if @data-counter as Int is greater than 4
     add @disabled -- disable after the 5th click

title: Strings {#strings}
description: Hyperscript supports strings that use either a single quotes or double quotes:
raw_code:
set hello to 'hello'
set world to "world"
set helloWorld to hello + " " + world

title: Strings {#strings}
description: and also supports JavaScript style template strings:
raw_code: set helloWorld to `${hello} ${world}`

title: Strings {#strings}
description: The [`append`](/commands/append) command can append content to strings (as well as to arrays and the DOM):
raw_code:
get "hello"      -- set result to "hello"
  append " world"  -- append " world" to the result
  log it           -- log it to the console

title: Calling Functions {#calling-functions}
description:
There are many ways to invoke functions in hyperscript.  Two commands let you invoke a function and automatically
assign the result to the `result` variable: [`call` and `get`](/commands/call):
raw_code:
call alert('hello world!')
get the nextInteger() then log it -- using the 'it' alias for 'result`

title: Events & Event Handlers {#event}
description: Respond to events only in certain cases, either with counts (e.g. `on click 1`) or with event filters (`on keyup[key is 'Escape']`)
raw_code: on keyup[key is 'Escape']

title: The Every Modifier {#on_every}
description:
An event handler with the `every` modifier will execute the event handler for every event that is received,
 even if the preceding handler execution has not finished.
raw_code: on every click add .clicked
html_context:
<button _="on every click add .clicked">
  Add The "clicked" Class To Me
</button>

title: Mutation Events {#mutation}
description: hyperscript includes a few synthetic events that make it easier to use more complex APIs in JavaScript.
raw_code: on mutation of @foo put "Mutated" into me

title: Intersection Events {#intersection}
description:
Here is a div that is set to `content-editable='true'` and that listens to mutations and updates a mutation count
below:
raw_code:
on intersection(intersecting) having threshold 0.5
        if intersecting transition opacity to 1
        else transition opacity to 0

title: Init Blocks {#init}
description: If you have logic that you wish to run when an element is initialized, you can use the `init` block to do so:
raw_code: init transition my opacity to 100% over 3 seconds
html_context: Fade Me In

title: Exception Handling {#exceptions}
description: Both functions and event handlers may have a `catch` block associated with them:
raw_code:
def example
  call mightThrowAnException()
catch e
  log e
end

on click
  call mightThrowAnException()
catch e
  log e
end

title: Exception Handling {#exceptions}
description: This allows you to handle exceptions that occur during the execution of the function or event handler.
raw_code:
on exception(error)
     log "An error occurred: " + error

title: Finally Blocks {#finally}
description: Both functions and event handlers also support a `finally` block to ensure that some cleanup code is executed:
raw_code:
on click
  add @disabled to me
  fetch /example
  put the result after me
finally
  remove @disabled from me

title: Throwing Exceptions {#throw}
description: You may throw an exception using the familiar `throw` keyword:
raw_code:
on click
  if I do not match .selected
    throw "I am not selected!"
  ...

title: DOM Literals {#dom-literals}
description: Here are a few examples of these literals in action:
raw_code:
-- adds the 'disabled' class to the element with the id 'myDiv'
add .disabled to #myDiv

-- adds the 'highlight' class to all divs with the class 'tabs' on them
add .highlight to <div.tabs/>

-- sets the width of the current element to 35 pixels
set my *width to 35px

-- adds the `disabled` attribute to the current element
add @disabled to me

title: DOM Literals {#dom-literals}
description: This allows you to look up elements based on a variable rather than a fixed value:
raw_code:
-- adds the 'disabled' class to the element with the id 'myDiv'
set idToDisable to 'myDiv'
add .disabled to #{idToDisable}

-- adds the 'highlight' class to all elements with the 'tabs' class
set classToHighlight to 'tabs'
add .highlight to .{classToHighlight}

-- removes all divs w/ class .hidden on them from the DOM
set elementType to 'div'
remove <${elementType}.hidden/>

title: DOM Literals {#dom-literals}
description: with the corresponding hyperscript:
raw_code:
on click from #example-btn
  remove .elements-to-remove

title: Finding Things In Other Things {#in}
description: Often you want to find things *within* a particular element.  To do this you can use the `in` expression:
raw_code:
-- add the class 'highlight' to all paragraph tags in the current element
add .highlight to <p/> in me

title: Finding The Closest Matching (Parent) Element {#closest}
description: To do this in hyperscript you can use the [`closest`](/expressions/closest) expression:
raw_code:
-- add the class 'highlight' to the closest table row to the current element
add .highlight to the closest <tr/>

title: Finding The Closest Matching (Parent) Element {#closest}
description:
Note that `closest` starts with the current element
and recurses up the DOM from there.  If you wish to start at the parent instead, you can use this form:
raw_code:
-- add the class 'highlight' to the closest div to the current element, excluding the current element
add .highlight to the closest parent <div/>

title: Finding Things By Position {#positional}
description:
You can use the [positional expressions](/expressions/positional) to get the first, last or a random element from
a collection of things:
raw_code:
-- add the class 'highlight' to the first paragraph tag in the current element
add .highlight to the first <p/> in me

title: Finding Things Relative To Other Things {#relative_positional}
description:
You can use the [relative positional expressions](/expressions/relative-positional) `next` and `previous` to get an element
 relative to either the current element, or to another element:
raw_code:
-- add the class 'highlight' to the next paragraph found in a forward scan of the DOM
add .highlight to the next <p/>

title: Set & Put {#set-and-put}
description: The `put` command can be used in the following ways:
raw_code: put [[content]] before [[element]]

title: Set & Put {#set-and-put}
description: The `put` command can be used in the following ways:
raw_code: put [[content]] at the start of [[element]]

title: Set & Put {#set-and-put}
description: The `put` command can be used in the following ways:
raw_code: put [[content]] at the end of [[element]]

title: Set & Put {#set-and-put}
description: The `put` command can be used in the following ways:
raw_code: put [[content]] after [[element]]

title: The `async` keyword {#async-keyword}
description: So, if you wanted to invoke a method that returns a promise, say `returnsAPromise()` but not wait on it to return, you write code like this:
raw_code: on click async call returnsAPromise() put 'I called it...' into the next <output/>
html_context:
<button _="on click async call returnsAPromise() put 'I called it...' into the next <output/>">
  Get The Answer...
</button>

title: Calling JavaScript {#js-call}
description: Any JavaScript function may be called directly from Hyperscript. See: [calling functions](#calling-functions).
raw_code: on click call alert('Hello from JavaScript!')
html_context:
<button _="on click call alert('Hello from JavaScript!')">
  Click me.
</button>

title: Inline JavaScript {#js-inline}
description: Inline JavaScript may be defined using the [`js` keyword](/features/js).
raw_code: init js alert('Hello from JavaScript!') end

title: Inline JavaScript {#js-inline}
description: Return values are supported.
raw_code: on click js return 'Success!' end then put it into my.innerHTML
html_context:
<button _="on click js return 'Success!' end then put it into my.innerHTML">
 Click me.
</button>

title: Inline JavaScript {#js-inline}
description: Parameters are supported.
raw_code: on click set foo to 1 js(foo) alert('Adding 1 to foo: '+(foo+1)) end
html_context:
<button _="on click set foo to 1 js(foo) alert('Adding 1 to foo: '+(foo+1)) end">
 Click me.
</button>

title: Behaviors {#behaviors}
description:
We have covered the basics (and not-so-basics) of hyperscript.  Now we come to the more advanced
features of the language.
raw_code:
behavior Removable
  on click
    remove me
  end
end

title: Behaviors {#behaviors}
description: They can accept arguments:
raw_code:
behavior Removable(removeButton)
  on click from removeButton
    remove me
  end
end

title: Behaviors {#behaviors}
description: They can be installed as shown:
raw_code: install Removable(removeButton: #close-banner)
html_context:
<div class="banner" _="install Removable(removeButton: #close-banner)">
  ...

title: Web Workers {#workers}
description:
[WebWorkers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Using_web_workers) can be defined
inline in hyperscript by using the [`worker` keyword](/features/worker).
raw_code: on click call Incrementer.increment(41) then put 'The answer is: ' + it into my.innerHTML
html_context:
<script type="text/hyperscript">
  worker Incrementer
    def increment(i)
      return i + 1
    end
  end
</script>
<button _="on click call Incrementer.increment(41) then put 'The answer is: ' + it into my.innerHTML">
  Call a Worker...
</button>

title: Web Sockets {#sockets}
description: Here is a simple web socket declaration in hyperscript:
raw_code:
socket MySocket ws://myserver.com/example
  on message as json
    log message
end

title: Event Source {#event-source}
description: Here is an example event source in hyperscript:
raw_code:
eventsource ChatUpdates from http://myserver.com/chat-updates

  on message as string
    put it into #div
  end

  on open
    log "connection opened."
  end

end

title: Debugging {#debugging}
raw_code: get <div.highlighted/> then log the result

title: Beeping
description: This is a reasonable way to start debugging but it is, obviously, fairly primitive.
raw_code: add .highlighted to <p/> in <div.hilight/>

title: Beeping
description: If this wasn't behaving as you expect and you wanted to debug the results, you might break it up like so:
raw_code:
set highlightDiv to <div.hilight/>
  log highlightDiv
  set highlightParagraphs to <p/> in highlightDiv
  log highlightParagraphs
  add .highlighted to highlightParagraphs

title: Beeping
description: So, considering the above code, rather than breaking things up, we might just try this:
raw_code: add .highlighted to <p/> in beep! <div.hilight/>

title: Beeping
description: We could now move the `beep!` out to the `in` expression like so:
raw_code: add .highlighted to beep! <p/> in <div.hilight/>

title: Beeping
description: After making the fix, we can remove the `beep!` (which is *obviously* not supposed to be there!):
raw_code: add .highlighted to <p/> in <div.highlight/>

title: Extending {#extending}
description: With this command defined you can now write the following hyperscript:
raw_code:
def testFoo()
    set str to "foo"
    foo str
  end

title: An easy & approachable language for modern web front-ends
description: <figure>
raw_code:
on pointerdown
  repeat until event pointerup from the document
    set rand to Math.random() * 360
    transition
      *background-color
      to `hsl($rand 100% 90%)`
      over 250ms
  end
  transition *background-color to initial

title: Events are first class citizens
raw_code:
on click send hello to <form />

on hello alert('got event')
html_context:
<button _="on click send hello to <form />">Send</button>

<form _="on hello alert('got event')">

title: Be async with no extra code
raw_code:
on click wait 5s send hello to .target

init fetch https://stuff as json then put result into me
html_context: Using fetch() API...

title: Enhance existing code
raw_code:
init js alert('Hello from JavaScript!') end

init js(haystack) return /needle/gi.exec(haystack) end

install Draggable(dragHandle: .titlebar)

title: Remember [HyperCard](https://hypercard.org/HyperTalk%20Reference%202.4.pdf)?
raw_code:
on click tell <p/> in me add .highlight

tell <details /> in .article set you.open to false
html_context:
<div _="on click tell <p/> in me add .highlight">

<div _="tell <details /> in .article set you.open to false">

title: Debugging and extending
description: **Graphically [debug](/docs#debugging)** and step through code as it runs.
raw_code: on click breakpoint

title: A start on our keyboard shortcut
description: Hyperscript code example
raw_code: on keydown[altKey and code is 'KeyS'] ...

title: Listening globally
description: Hyperscript code example
raw_code: on keydown[altKey and code is 'KeyS'] from window ...

title: HTML with Hyperscript
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code:
on click
increment the textContent of the previous <output/>
html_context: 0

title: Listening globally
description: Hyperscript embedded in HTML
raw_code:
on keydown[altKey and code is 'KeyS'] from the window
focus() me
html_context:
<input id="search" name="q" type="search" placeholder="Search Contacts"
  _="on keydown[altKey and code is 'KeyS'] from the window
    focus() me"> <1>

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
(underscore) attribute for putting scripting on DOM
elements. You may also use the

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
attributes, depending on your HTML validation needs.

Lets look at how to implement the simple counter component we have been looking
at using \_hyperscript. We will place an

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
. To implement the counter, we will need to add a
small bit of \_hyperscript to the button. On a click, the button should
increment the text of the previous

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
html
0

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
. Which one you use should depend on which one is most readable.
-

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
,
\_hyperscript does not shy away from using DOM-specific, non-natural language
when appropriate.]

==== \_hyperscript in Action: A Keyboard Shortcut <_hyperscript_in_action_a_keyboard_shortcut>
While the counter demo is a good way to compare various approaches to scripting,
the rubber meets the road when you try to actually implement a useful feature
with an approach. For \_hyperscript, lets add a keyboard shortcut to
Contact.app: when a user hits Alt+S in our app, we will focus the search field.

Since our keyboard shortcut focuses the search input, lets put the code for it
on that search input, satisfying locality.

Here is the original HTML for the search input:

#figure[

title: Inline Hyperscript Example

raw_code:
]

#index[\_hyperscript][event listener]
#index[\_hyperscript][event filter]
#index[\_hyperscript][filter expression]
We will add an event listener using the

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
hyperscript
on keydown[altKey and code is 'KeyS'] ...

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
]

#index[\_hyperscript][from]
Now, by default, \_hyperscript will listen for a given event _on the element where it is declared_.
So, with the script we have, we would only get

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
from the
window, and our code ends up looking, naturally, like this:

#figure(caption: [Listening globally])[

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
hyperscript
on keydown[altKey and code is 'KeyS'] from window ...

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
clause, we can attach the listener to the window while, at the
same time, keeping the code on the element it logically relates to.

Now that weve picked out the event we want to use to focus the search box,
lets implement the actual focusing by calling the standard

title: Inline Hyperscript Example
description: Inline hyperscript code
raw_code:
html
<input id="search" name="q" type="search" placeholder="Search Contacts"
  _="on keydown[altKey and code is 'KeyS'] from the window
    focus() me"> <1>
